sen.j: 山田 宗徧（やまだ そうへん、寛永4年（1627年） - 宝永5年4月2日 (旧暦)（1708年5月21日））は、江戸時代前期の茶人。
sen.e: Born in 1627 and gone on May 21, 1708, Sohen YAMADA was "chajin" (a master on the art of the tea ceremony) in the first half of the Edo period.
Born in 1627 and gone on May 21, 1708, Sohen YAMADA was "chajin" (a master on the art of the tea ceremony) from the first half of the Edo period.
Born in 1627 and gone on May 21, 1708, Sohen YAMADA was chajin (a master on the art of the tea ceremony) from the first half of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: 宗偏流茶道を興した茶人として茶道界でも高名だが、一般には元禄赤穂事件（忠臣蔵事件）の際に大高源五に吉良邸茶会の日を教えた人物として有名。
sen.e: In the tea ceremony community, he is famous as the chajin who founded Sohen school, but in general, he is known as the person who taught the date of the tea ceremony at Kira's residence to "Gengo OTAKA" on the occasion of "Genroku Ako Incident" (the Chusingura incident).

In the tea ceremony community, he is famous as a chajin who founded the Sohen school, but in general, he is known as the person who instructed people on the date of the tea ceremony at Kira's residence to "Gengo OTAKA" during an occasion known as "Genroku Ako Incident" (the Chusingura incident).

In the tea ceremony community, he is famous as a chajin who founded the Sohen school, but in general, he is known as the person who instructed people on the date of the tea ceremony at Kira's residence to Gengo OTAKA during an occasion known as Genroku Ako Incident (the Chusingura incident).
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: 茶号は四方庵・不審庵・今日庵。
sen.e: His pseudonyms as a chajin were "Yoho-an," "Fushin-an," and "Konnichi-an."
His pseudonyms as a chajin were "Yoho-an," "Fushin-an," and "Konnichi-an."
His pseudonyms as a chajin were Yoho-an, Fushin-an, and Konnichi-an.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: 寛永4年（1627年）、東本願寺末寺である京都上京二本松長徳寺の住職明覚（長徳寺四世）の子として長徳寺に生まれた。
sen.e: In 1627, he was born in Chotoku-ji Temple as a child of Myokaku (the fourth heir of the Chotoku-ji Temple), who was the chief priest of Chotoku-ji Temple (a branch temple of Higashi Hongan-ji Temple) at the present Nihonmatsu, Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.

In 1627, he was born in Chotoku-ji Temple as a child of Myokaku (the fourth heir of the Chotoku-ji Temple), who was the chief priest of Chotoku-ji Temple (a branch temple of Higashi Hongan-ji Temple) at the present Nihonmatsu, Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.

In 1627, he was born in Chotoku-ji Temple as a child of Myokaku (the fourth heir of the Chotoku-ji Temple), who was the chief priest of Chotoku-ji Temple (a branch temple of Higashi Hongan-ji Temple) at the present Nihonmatsu, Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 母は山田監物（松江藩主堀尾忠晴重臣）の娘。
sen.e: His mother was the daughter of "Kenmotsu YAMADA" (the senior vassal of "Tadaharu HORIO," the head of the Matsue Clan).
His mother was the daughter of "Kenmotsu YAMADA" (the senior vassal of "Tadaharu HORIO," the head of the Matsue Clan).
His mother was the daughter of Kenmotsu YAMADA (the senior vassal of Tadaharu HORIO, the head of the Matsue Clan).
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: 僧名は、周覚・周学（しゅうがく）。
sen.e: His name as a Buddhist priest was "Shukaku" or "Shugaku."
His name as a Buddhist priest was "Shukaku" or "Shugaku."
His name as a Buddhist priest was Shukaku or Shugaku.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: 父から寺の住職職を継いだが、還俗して茶道を志すようになり、小堀遠州に入門。
sen.e: He inherited the position of the chief priest from his father, but he aspired to the art of the tea ceremony, so he returned to the secular life and became a pupil of "Enshu KOBORI."
He inherited the position of the chief priest from his father, but he aspired to learn the art of tea ceremony, so he returned to the secular life and became a pupil of "Enshu KOBORI."
He inherited the position of the chief priest from his father, but he aspired to learn the art of tea ceremony, so he returned to the secular life and became a pupil of Enshu KOBORI.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: さらに正保元年（1644年）、18歳のときに千宗旦に弟子入りする。
sen.e: Then in 1644, at the age of 18, he became a pupil of "SEN no Sotan."
Then in 1644, at the age of 18, he became a pupil of "SEN no Sotan."
Then in 1644, at the age of 18, he became a pupil of SEN no Sotan.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: 承保元年（1652年）宗旦の皆伝を受け、京都郊外の鳴滝村三宝寺に茶室を建てた。
sen.e: In 1652, he was conferred full mastership by Sotan, so he built a teahouse on the premises of Sanpo-ji Temple in Narutaki Village, a suburb of Kyoto.
In 1652, he was conferred full mastership by Sotan, so he built a teahouse on the premises of Sanpo-ji Temple in Narutaki Village, a suburb of Kyoto.
In 1652, he was conferred full mastership by Sotan, so he built a teahouse on the premises of Sanpo-ji Temple in Narutaki Village, a suburb of Kyoto.

sen.j: このお祝いに宗旦から千利休の伝来の品である四方釜を譲られた。
sen.e: Sotan transferred "yoho gama" (an iron pot having a square body) handed down from "SEN no Rikyu" to him.
Sotan transferred "yoho gama" (an iron pot having a square body) handed down from "SEN no Rikyu" to him.
Sotan transferred yoho gama (an iron pot having a square body) handed down from SEN no Rikyu to him.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: また大徳寺の翠厳和尚からも「四方庵」の茶号を贈られている。
sen.e: And Buddhist priest Suigen at Daitoku-ji Temple conferred the pseudonym of "Yoho-an" to him.
And Buddhist priest Suigen at Daitoku-ji Temple conferred the pseudonym of "Yoho-an" to him.
And Buddhist priest Suigen at Daitoku-ji Temple conferred the pseudonym of 'Yoho-an' to him.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: 明暦元年（1655年）、千宗旦の推挙で三河国吉田藩（愛知県豊橋市）主小笠原忠知に茶道をもって30石5人扶持（100石格）で仕えるようになった。
sen.e: In 1655, on the recommendation of Sen no Sotan, he began to serve "Tadatomo OGASAWARA," who was the lord of the Yoshida Domain in Mikawa Province (the present Toyohashi City, Aichi Prefecture), with his art on the tea ceremony at a formal stipend of 100 koku (a real stipend of 30 koku, a ration for five persons).

In 1655, on a recommendation by Sen no Sotan, he began to serve "Tadatomo OGASAWARA," who was a lord of the Yoshida Domain in Mikawa Province (the present Toyohashi City, Aichi Prefecture), and received a formal stipend of 100 koku (a real stipend of 30 koku, a ration enough for five persons) to carry out the art of tea ceremony.

In 1655, on a recommendation by SEN no Sotan, he began to serve Tadatomo OGASAWARA, who was a lord of the Yoshida Domain in Mikawa Province (the present Toyohashi City, Aichi Prefecture), and received a formal stipend of 100 koku (a real stipend of 30 koku, a ration enough for five persons) to carry out the art of tea ceremony.
sen.cmt: Sen no Sotan→SEN no Sotanに修正、クォーテーション削除

sen.j: また長徳寺を離れるにあたって、母方の姓山田をとって｢山田宗徧家定｣と改名している。
sen.e: When he left Chotoku-ji Temple, he was renamed "Sohen Iesada YAMADA" after his mother's family name "Yamada."
When he left Chotoku-ji Temple, he was renamed "Sohen Iesada YAMADA" after his mother's family name "Yamada."
When he left Chotoku-ji Temple, he was renamed 'Sohen Iesada YAMADA' after his mother's family name 'Yamada.'
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: 父明覚も山田道玄と改名した。
sen.e: His father Myokaku was also renamed "Dogen YAMADA."
His father Myokaku was also renamed "Dogen YAMADA."
His father Myokaku was also renamed Dogen YAMADA.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: 万治元年（1658年）に千宗旦が死ぬと茶統をついで不審庵四世となる（一世は千利休）（表千家がよく用いる）。
sen.e: When SEN no Sotan died in 1658, Sohen inherited the traditional art of the tea ceremony from Sotan and became the fourth heir of the pseudonym Fushin-an; incidentally, the pseudonym has been used frequently by "Omotesenke" (the family of Omotesen) and the first Fushin-an was SEN no Rikyu.

When SEN no Sotan died in 1658, Sohen inherited the traditional art of tea ceremony from Sotan and became the fourth heir of the pseudonym Fushin-an; incidentally, the pseudonym has been used frequently by "Omotesenke" (the family of Omotesen) and the first Fushin-an was SEN no Rikyu.

When SEN no Sotan died in 1658, Sohen inherited the traditional art of tea ceremony from Sotan and became the fourth heir of the pseudonym Fushin-an; incidentally, the pseudonym has been used frequently by Omotesenke (the family of Omotesen) and the first Fushin-an was SEN no Rikyu.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: また、今日庵も譲られる（裏千家がよく用いる）。
sen.e: And the pseudonym Konnichi-an was also transferred to Sohen; incidentally, this pseudonym has been used frequently by "Urasenke" (the family of Urasen).
And the pseudonym Konnichi-an was also transferred to Sohen; incidentally, this pseudonym has been used frequently by "Urasenke" (the family of Urasen).
And the pseudonym Konnichi-an was also transferred to Sohen; incidentally, this pseudonym has been used frequently by Urasenke (the family of Urasen).
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: 吉田で与えられた屋敷は今は豊橋公園（豊橋市今橋町）の一角となっている（現在、石碑が有る）。
sen.e: His premises given in the Yoshida Domain now become a part of Toyohashi-koen Park in Imahashi Town, Toyohashi City; a stone monument stands there at present.
His premises given in the Yoshida Domain now become a part of Toyohashi-koen Park in Imahashi Town, Toyohashi City; a stone monument stands there at present.
His premises given in the Yoshida Domain now become a part of Toyohashi-koen Park in Imahashi-cho, Toyohashi City; a stone monument stands there at present.
sen.cmt: 現住所のため、Imahashi Town→Imahshi-choとし、余分なスペースを消去

sen.j: 臨済寺 (豊橋市東田町）で参禅得道し、栽松庵を設けた。
sen.e: He did "sanzentokudo" (Zen meditation and attaining salvation) at Rinzai-ji Temple (in the present Azumada Town, Toyohashi City) and he built Saisho-an Hermitage there.
He did "sanzentokudo" (Zen meditation and attaining salvation) at Rinzai-ji Temple (in the present Azumada Town, Toyohashi City) and he built Saisho-an Hermitage there.
He did sanzentokudo (Zen meditation and attaining salvation) at Rinzai-ji Temple (in the present Azumada-cho, Toyohashi City) and he built Saisho-an Hermitage there.
sen.cmt: 現住所のため、Azumada Town→Azumada-choとし、クォーテーション削除

sen.j: また、飯村（いむれ、同市飯村町）や小坂井（こざかい、愛知県宝飯郡小坂井町）に大名接待の茶屋を設立した。
sen.e: And he built "chaya" (tea houses) for entertaining "daimyo" (feudal lords) in Imure (the present Imure Town, Toyohashi City), Kozakai (the present Kozakai Town, Hoi County, Aichi Prefecture) and other places.

And he built "chaya" (tea houses) for entertaining "daimyo" (feudal lords) in Imure (the present Imure Town, Toyohashi City), Kozakai (the present Kozakai Town, Hoi County, Aichi Prefecture) and other places.
And he built chaya (tea houses) for entertaining daimyo (feudal lords) in Imure (the present Imure-cho, Toyohashi City), Kozakai (the present Kozakai-cho, Hoi-gun, Aichi Prefecture) and other places.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除、現住所のため、Imure Town→Imure-cho、Kozakai Town, Hoi County→Kozakai-cho, Hoi-gunに修正

sen.j: 以降40年以上にわたり小笠原氏に仕える。
sen.e: Thereafter, he served the Ogasawara clan for more than 40 years.
Thereafter, he served the Ogasawara clan for more than 40 years.
Thereafter, he served the Ogasawara clan for more than 40 years.

sen.j: 元禄10年(1697年)、吉田小笠原家の職を二世宗引へ譲って吉田を去り、東海道を江戸に下り、本所に居を構える。
sen.e: In 1697, Sohen transferred his job at the Ogasawara family in the Yoshida Domain to the second Soin, and then he left there, went down Tokai-do Road for Edo and settled down in Honjo.
In 1697, Sohen transferred his job at the Ogasawara family in the Yoshida Domain to the second Soin, and then he left and went down Tokai-do Road for Edo and settled down in Honjo.
In 1697, Sohen transferred his job at the Ogasawara family in the Yoshida Domain to the second Soin, and then he left and went down Tokai-do Road for Edo and settled down in Honjo.

sen.j: 宗徧流茶道を興した。
sen.e: He founded Sohen school on the art of the tea ceremony.
He founded the Sohen school for the art of the tea ceremony.
He founded the Sohen school for the art of the tea ceremony.

sen.j: 元禄赤穂事件の際には、吉良上野介（上野介も千宗旦の弟子の一人だった）が本所に屋敷替えになった後にはしばしば吉良邸の茶会に招かれて出席している。
sen.e: Before Genroku Ako Incident, Sohen frequently attended the tea ceremony at Kira's residence at the invitation of "Kozukenosuke KIRA," who was also the pupil of SEN no Sotan, because the residence of Kozukenosuke was transferred to Honjo.

Before Genroku Ako Incident, Sohen frequently attended the tea ceremony at Kira's residence at the invitation of "Kozukenosuke KIRA," who was also the pupil of SEN no Sotan, because the residence of Kozukenosuke was transferred to Honjo.

Before Genroku Ako Incident, Sohen frequently attended the tea ceremony at Kira's residence at the invitation of Kozukenosuke KIRA, who was also the pupil of SEN no Sotan, because the residence of Kozukenosuke was transferred to Honjo.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: そのため、脇屋新兵衛（その正体は赤穂四十七士の一人大高源五）が宗徧に弟子入りし、宗徧から「12月14日に吉良邸で茶会」という情報を聞きだすことに成功した。
sen.e: And so, "Shinbei WAKIYA," whose real identity was Gengo OTAKA (one of 47 samurai of Ako), became a pupil of Sohen, and Gengo succeeded in getting the information from Sohen that a tea ceremony would be held at Kira's residence on January 30, 1703.

And so, "Shinbei WAKIYA," whose real identity was Gengo OTAKA (one of 47 samurai of Ako), became a pupil of Sohen, and Gengo succeeded in obtaining information from Sohen concerning a tea ceremony which was to be held at Kira's residence on January 30, 1703.

And so, Shinbei WAKIYA, whose real identity was Gengo OTAKA (one of 47 samurai of Ako), became a pupil of Sohen, and Gengo succeeded in obtaining information from Sohen concerning a tea ceremony which was to be held at Kira's residence on January 30, 1703.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: 大石内蔵助は、この日を吉良上野介在宅確実の日と考え、討ち入り日と決定するのである。
sen.e: Being sure that Kozukenosuke would be at home on this date, "Kuranosuke OISHI" decided to make a raid on Kira's residence on the date.
Being sure that Kozukenosuke would be at home on this date, "Kuranosuke OISHI" decided to make a raid on Kira's residence on the date.
Being sure that Kozukenosuke would be at home on this date, Kuranosuke OISHI decided to make a raid on Kira's residence on the date.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: 一説に実は山田宗徧は脇屋新兵衛の正体を知りながら赤穂義士達の無念を思いやってわざと吉良邸茶会の日を教えたともいわれる。
sen.e: Some say that Sohen YAMADA actually knew Shinbei WAKIYA's real identity and that Sohen intentionally taught the date of the tea ceremony at Kira's residence considering the regret of Ako's loyal vassals.

Some say that Sohen YAMADA actually knew Shinbei WAKIYA's real identity and that Sohen intentionally gave the date of the tea ceremony at Kira's residence after taking into consideration the regret held by Ako's loyal vassals.

Some say that Sohen YAMADA actually knew Shinbei WAKIYA's real identity and that Sohen intentionally gave the date of the tea ceremony at Kira's residence after taking into consideration the regret held by Ako's loyal vassals.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを消去

sen.j: 宝永5年（1708年）4月2日に江戸で死去。
sen.e: On May 21, 1708, Sohen passed away in Edo.
On May 21, 1708, Sohen passed away in Edo.
On May 21, 1708, Sohen passed away in Edo.

sen.j: 享年82。
sen.e: He died at the age of 82.
He died at the age of 82.
He died at the age of 82.

sen.j: 浅草本願寺中の願竜寺に葬られたが、遺言により墓石は建てていない。
sen.e: He was buried on the premises of Ganryu-ji Temple within Asakusa Hongan-ji Temple, but there is no gravestone under his will.
He was buried on the premises of Ganryu-ji Temple within Asakusa Hongan-ji Temple, but no gravestone was erected according to his will.
He was buried on the premises of Ganryu-ji Temple within Asakusa Hongan-ji Temple, but no gravestone was erected according to his will.

sen.j: 石灯竜（享保の大火で消失）、紅梅（関東大震災で消失）だけを残した。
sen.e: Instead, only a stone lantern, which later disappeared in "Kyoho no taika" (Great Fire of Kyoho), & a plum tree with red blossoms, which later disappeared in the Great Kanto Earthquake, were left.
Instead, only a stone lantern, which later disappeared in "Kyoho no taika" (Great Fire of Kyoho), & a plum tree with red blossoms, which later disappeared in the Great Kanto Earthquake, were left.
Instead, only a stone lantern, which later disappeared in the Great Fire of Kyoho, and a plum tree with red blossoms, which later disappeared in the Great Kanto Earthquake, were left.
sen.cmt: "Kyoho no taika" (Great Fire of Kyoho)→the Great Fire of Kyohoのみとし、&→andに修正

sen.j: 法名は不審庵周学宗徧居士。
sen.e: His posthumous Buddhist name is "Fushinan shugaku sohen koji."
His posthumous Buddhist name is "Fushinan shugaku sohen koji."
His posthumous Buddhist name is Fushinan shugaku sohen koji.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: 著書に『茶道便蒙抄』『茶道要録』などがある。
sen.e: He wrote "Sado benmosho," "Sado Yoroku" and others.
He wrote "Sado benmosho," "Sado Yoroku" and others.
He wrote "Sado Benmosho," "Sado Yoroku" and others.

tit.cmt: 頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 妻は生駒氏。
sen.e: His wife came from the Ikoma clan.
His wife came from the Ikoma clan.
His wife came from the Ikoma clan.

sen.j: 男子が三人おり、長男宗倫は早世したが、次男山田宗屋と三男生駒権平宗俊は小笠原家に近習として仕えた。
sen.e: Of his three sons, the first son Sorin died young, but the second son "Sooku YAMADA" & the third son "Gonpei munetoshi IKOMA" both served the Ogasawara family as its "kinju" (attendants).
Of his three sons, the first son Sorin died young, but the second son "Sooku YAMADA" & the third son "Gonpei munetoshi IKOMA" both served the Ogasawara family as its "kinju" (attendants).
Of his three sons, the first son Sorin died young, but the second son Sooku YAMADA and the third son Gonpei Munetoshi IKOMA both served the Ogasawara family as its kinju (attendants).
sen.cmt: &→andに修正、クォーテーション削除、munetoshi→Munetoshiに修正
